reviewText: TRUE ADOLESCENTS (Writ./Dir. Craig Johnson, 2009, 88 minutes) ~'Cousin' Sam-- Mark Duplass (commonly seen on TV and in small roles such asParkland, see my review, andZero Dark Thirty)Oliver ("Ollie")-- Bret Loehr (now a gorgeous young man but still a little too thin in the résumé)Jake-- Carr Thompson (equally now-cute, little-known yet recognizable TV bit-player who stopped working in 2011 to attend UCLA)This is a film I loved, with its intense yet lightly treated story arc and an important stillness, a silence that too many filmmakers misunderstand, and therefore rarely use. It helped that this was set in/around Seattle and a Washington state park, lavishly beautiful. There are thorns on this rose, to be sure, but then they may only be personal gripes.Sam (a handsome and talented Mark Duplass), a 30-something washed-up rock musician, moves in with his aunt and her son Oliver. When Cousin Sam, Oliver and Oliver's best friend Jake go on a camping trip, things get emotionally intense and at times weird. Don't let any of this fool you: the film is incredibly funny, mostly due to Uncle Sam's grumpy-old-man demeanor and hilarious swearing. (Definitely not a wholesome family film due to that but these days, who cares except religiously strict people?)One tremendous problem I had with this is the age difference. Cousin Sam is about 34, while his cousin Oliver and Oliver's friend Jake are 14. It's bad enough Duplass looks to be around 40 years old. It troubled me because it only made sense that Duplass should play the uncle, not a weirdly miscast cousin-once-removed.There is exploration for the boys, with a blossoming relationship that I felt was treated realistically--but the director here simply abandons one scene after another in pursuit of more humor and less emotion. The movie thus allows us to instruct ourselves and take from it what we like. Problem is, it is still a half-abandoned movie.People have to stop taking this cowardly road especially when a 'young gay romance' is part of the plot. This movie is supposed to be about a relatively young man who is entering his midlife crisis with a parallel story about his possibly gay young cousin and the cousin's boyfriend. In other words, it is deeply satisfying on some levels while it is totally empty on other levels. Part of it is a waste, yet I found somehow that wasted time allowed me to think about it more deeply. Either the director is a stunning genius or he just lucked out!Let me quote an excellent colleague's sage words (K. Harris, than you): "There is a type of film that capitalizes on slight situations with meandering narratives and seemingly improvisational dialogue. Labeled as mumblecore ... " and then Harris goes on to say these types of films are generally about college-age loser types.TRUE ADOLESCENTS is not that at all--though Uncle Sam is the consummate post-college aimless loser type. He begins to 'find himself' through his almost-equals contact with the teens (for example, he learns that a grown-up by nature should not be horning in on them too much; later he discovers he can converse more easily with them than with anyone). As to the term "mumblecore", I think that relates to the half-swallowed lines and poor sound associated with such films.If the sound is good, the lines are spoken realistically, then hey!!--you've just hit a major level of enlightenment realizing HALF the damned country mumbles! It makes a film more real and causes you to lean in and listen more carefully, if done correctly. I've seen way too many Hollyweird billion-dollar productions with this kind of line-mumbling problem and that is the inexcusable tragedy.This indie TV film is a gently flawed gem and I suggest you see it. The soundtrack is awesome with a few songs I recognized and love. There are hints in this movie of everything fromDutchto Rainn Wilson's 2008 star vehicleThe Rockerto the spectacularGeography Club(see my review).My only real problem is this film appears to be all about Sam, with the boys as cardboard-cutout background. Exemplary is when Sam butts in on his young cousin who is making out with his boyfriend. Sam is unfazed and sorry he interrupted them--but after a tense minute or so, the entire situation is abandoned.Now, hear me: that is the kind of cinema you don't just abandon as soon as you feel like it. It has to be followed through, it has to be nourished and evolve throughout the film. I think films with kids in them--and most especially gay kids--ought to concentrate on the kids. Imagine kids watching this and being made to feel even more adrift by the way they are represented in film.
summary: "Let me know when you're tired, and I'll tell you to grow some balls."

reviewText: This quiet film stealthily approaches some rather profound questions about growing up, finding an identity, maturing, and developing a sense of responsibility--and it just kind of leaves them there, unanswered. That's not to say the film is without merit. Mark Duplass is perfectly cast as Sam, the 30something "true adolescent" who finds himself without a job, a girlfriend, or a home. While crashing at his aunt's place, he gets recruited to chaperone his cousin and his cousin's best friend on a camping trip. A silly prank in the middle of the trip accidentally uncovers a delicate moment, which propels much of the subsequent action of the film even as its importance remains marginalized and only tangentially alluded to as the movie progresses toward an inconclusive resolution. "True Adolescents" is what I would call a "problem film"--but one I enjoyed nonetheless (even though I still can't decide whether I actually like Mark Duplass).
summary: Unanswered questions about what it means to grow up

reviewText: There is a type of film that capitalizes on slight situations with meandering narratives and seemingly improvisational dialogue. Labeled as mumblecore, this indie film movement generally features characters in a post-college malaise struggling their way to adulthood. These are certainly not plot driven films, but movies that rely on character relatability and offbeat humor. If you've seen the works of the Duplass Brothers, Lynn Shelton, and Kelly Reichardt (although she tends to be more serious) among others--you've got a good sense about whether these films appeal to you or not. Craig Johnson's winning and very funny "True Adolescents" fits squarely into that niche. So if you hated other examples of this genre (Puffy Chair, Humpday, Cyrus), this may not be for you. I, however, was taken completely by surprise by how positively I reacted to this movie!Our slacker hero is played by Mark Duplass in perhaps his most well rounded role. A struggling musician at 34, he is left homeless when his current relationship comes to a conclusion. Moving in with his Aunt (Melissa Leo), he does everything he can to avoid responsibility as he waits for a big record deal to materialize. Taking his fourteen year old cousin and his best friend on a camping trip just might be the unlikely catalyst to jumpstart a path to grown-up living. The threesome starts out non-communicative, push through to confrontational, and move on to unexpected bonding. The trip takes a few twists and turns both harrowing and hilarious, but always maintains a hard-edged heart. That's an element I really appreciated, the film maintains a realistic feel by never succumbing to overt melodrama or grandstanding.Duplass is terrific and I thought the screenplay was witty and authentic. Johnson really captured how guys talk to one another, and I believed every bit of it. Of course, the film wouldn't have real indie cred without an appropriate soundtrack and the movie doesn't disappoint in that respect. For sheer enjoyment, this film was about 4 1/2 stars for me. I laughed out loud frequently especially in the first half. And just when I feared the film would go all soft, it maintains a refreshingly realistic aloofness. I'm rounding up for Duplass' fearless performance. But again, like many of the mumblecore films--you'll probably either love this or hate it. I loved it. KGHarris, 8/11.
summary: An Unexpectedly Delightful Indie Treat--While Not For Everyone, It's Funny And Realistic

reviewText: I love slice of life films. This one just kept you so interested with the rich dialogue and gorgeous scenery. I think the script was really smart. It does seem to be a little preachy but not over the top or in your face. Really funny parts balance the dramatic parts. My husband and I really enjoyed it. Will watch again!
